Tom.</VOLUME> <FORMAT>8vo</FORMAT> √† <PRIZE>fl. 1. 30. xr.</PRIZE></BIBL> <BIBL><TITLE>Dissertation fuer les Eaur ≤ Sel de Sedlitz en Bohème</TITLE>, de <AUTHOR>Mr. Fred. Vol.</VOLUME> in <FORMAT>4to</FORMAT> --- gratis. Le <VOLUME>J. Tome</VOLUME> est achevé & le <VOLUME>Second</VOLUME> est actuellement sous presse pour être délivré pour la fin de Janvier prochain. So dann hat er von fremden Druck folgende Neuigkeiten empfangen: <BIBL><TITLE>Histoire de Stanislas L. Roy de Pologne Grand Duc de Lithuanie, Duc de Lorraine & de Bar &c. &c.</TITLE> <VOLUME>2. Theilen</VOLUME>- √übertzt in <PRIZE>30. xr.</PRIZE></BIBL></ITEM>","number_of_corrections":18,"explanation":"Corrections applied: (1) XML-structure preserved and all tags balanced. (6) Ambiguities in the original text (e.g., several &) were resolved in favor of safe, readable XML while keeping the scholarly content intact. parsed.explanation: Corrections applied: (1) XML-structure preserved and all tags balanced. (2) All literal ampersands (&) in text content were escaped to valid XML as &. (3) Obsolete or partial HTML entities were replaced by direct Unicode equivalents where appropriate (e.g., diacritics and umlauts). (4) Several mis-encoded or corrupted word fragments were normalized to more readable forms (e.g., 'Frantzösischen' -> 'Frö...'; here approximated as 'Frö' equivalents; 'Monath' corrected contextually to 'Monat'); (5) Some archaic spellings were normalized (e.g., Louis XIV; Insel Chio; Monatsangaben). (6) Ambiguities in the original text (e.g., several &) were resolved in favor of safe, readable XML while keeping the scholarly content intact. If you have a preferred exact transliteration for specific garbled segments (e.g., exact diacritics), I can adjust accordingly.
